ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Prospective, passive, imperfective, perfective, and other grammatical forms, translation in a literary context
This class built on knowledge from L1 Egyptian by learning the rest of the grammar structures in the first half of the semester and then reading real texts in the second half

I learned many hieroglyphics and the grammatical structures that they use. Also got to translate real Egyptian texts. Definitely learned more this semester and had some things from last semester made clearer.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: In starting to read real Egyptian texts it was really useful to be able to work in groups and compare translations and transliterations, as well as parse through sections I wasn't as confident on.

The course was hard but run pretty well. It is just unfortunate that we have in class tests that are closed notes when in real life we will never have to translate hieroglyphics without having access to resources like our notes. It also really sucks to have it at 9 am in the morning because that is too early for me to really function and pay attention to something as complicated as hieroglyphics.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, this class is a great continuation of EGYP 110 that also provides an avenue to where you can apply the grammar that you have learned by reading texts.

Highly recommend, the class was challenging at times, but the content was interesting and the professor was highly engaging. Plus just being able to translate Egyptian texts is a really interesting skill

I would recommend this to someone who wants to learn ancient languages or just wants to try something that can only be offered at a place like Yale. Although I do have some regrets about not trying to learn a language that would actually be useful in my life.
